body:
The PERSON administration is preparing for nearly 180,000 migrants traveling as families to cross the southern border of the GPE by May, continuing an already record-breaking year.

According to an internal document reviewed by ORG, officials at ORG anticipate between 51,000 and 58,000 migrants traveling as families will either cross the border illegally or ask for asylum at a legal border crossing this month. The agency projects that figure will reach as many as 70,000 in May, based on historical trends.

NORP of families crossing the ORG border illegally in the past five months hit a record of 136,150. The tally eclipsed a record of 107,212 families arrested during the entire 2018 fiscal year.

Separately, 21,968 immigrant families asked for asylum at legal border crossings between October and February. The volume of families at those crossings was about the same a year ago.

The flood of families crossing the GPE border with GPE represents a “border security and humanitarian crisis” and has left ORG at “the breaking point,” ORG Commissioner PERSON said last week.

ORG declined to comment on the document, which is labeled “planning profile.”

Despite recent increases, the total number of arrests at the border has been hovering near lows not seen since the 1970s, primarily due to a long-term decline in single adults, who have been deterred by stepped-up enforcement and an improved NORP economy.

Most of the families so far this year are from GPE, GPE and GPE, where they say they face violence, political instability and widespread poverty and hunger. The majority of families surrender to border agents and ask for asylum after crossing into the GPE illegally. Fewer than 20% of all asylum applications are ultimately granted, but people with children are generally allowed to stay in the GPE while their requests are adjourned, which typically takes years due to a backlog of more than 829,000 cases in immigration court.

The PERSON administration has repeatedly tried to make changes to immigration laws and procedures to slow the flood of families, including a policy that led to separating families. A federal judge in GPE ordered the administration to reunite more than 2,500 separated children last year, a process that is ongoing.

That same judge on Friday ruled that a class-action lawsuit filed by ORG should include families separated before last year’s short-lived zero-tolerance policy, but didn’t yet order the government to locate those families. The ORG sued the government last year on behalf of an NORP woman separated from her child at a border crossing and the case was later expanded to a class-action suit.

President PERSON has cited the increasing volume of families as evidence of a national emergency at the border. He has repeatedly said current immigration laws and what he describes as flawed court rulings encourage illegal immigration because families, most of whom ask for asylum, cannot be detained for more than about 20 days.

If the more conservative of two projections on ORG document is accurate, about 178,000 people traveling as families will come into the GPE illegally, or legally to request asylum, between March and May, compared with fewer than 46,000 during the same period last year.

A 45-year-old undocumented immigrant from GPE died in FAC custody Monday after crossing the ORG border into GPE, marking the third person to die in the agency's custody since December.
The immigrant illegally crossed the border and was arrested by ORG on Feb. 2, requested medical attention and was taken to a local hospital, according to a statement released Monday night by ORG. The immigrant "was cleared" by officials at ORG and was handed over to ORG officials at FAC, according to the ORG statement.
The following day, after receiving a welfare check by ORG officials, the immigrant again requested medical attention and was taken to ORG, where the immigrant was diagnosed with cirrhosis of the liver and congestive heart failure, ORG said. The immigrant remained at the hospital before dying on Monday morning.
The incident follows two cases in December when minor children from GPE, ages 8 and 7, died after crossing the GPE border into GPE, drawing widespread condemnation of ORG.
That prompted ORG Commissioner PERSON to issue new guidelines requiring his agents to more quickly inform ORG leadership, ORG, and the public of the death of people in its custody. ORG Secretary PERSON later followed up by ordering more robust medical screenings of children it holds in its custody.
Those deaths followed intense criticism of the agency's handling of children during the administration's now-rescinded "zero-tolerance" that led to more than 2,800 family separations along the border.
ORG spokesman PERSON said the official cause of death in Monday's case remains unknown, and that the immigrant's identity is not being released. PERSON said the department is following newly-created notification guidelines following deaths in its custody, and has alerted ORG and the NORP government of the immigrant's death.
"This loss of life is tragic," PERSON said in a statement. "Our condolences go out to the family and loved ones. ORG remains committed to ensuring the safe and humane treatment of those within the care of our custody."
ORG officials have said they cannot handle the influx of family units and unaccompanied minors who have flooded the southwest border in recent years, many of them requesting asylum in the GPE
In the past four months, a monthly average of 24,975 members of family units and 5,031 unaccompanied minors have crossed the southern border, according to ORG data. The family unit average is far higher than the monthly average of 6,406 over the same period in 2018.
That surge has led the PERSON administration to try and limit the number of people who can request asylum, actions that have been blocked by the federal courts. The surge also contributed to President PERSON's decision on Friday to declare a national emergency to expand the southern border wall, which will also lead to a flood of lawsuits.
The new NORP-led ORG has vowed to investigate housing conditions for migrants along the border. Part of the budget deal that averted a government shutdown last week included $415 million for humanitarian relief "specifically for medical care" and to improve ORG processing facilities in the region.
ORG's summary of Monday's death did not indicate whether the immigrant was requesting asylum. It noted that the immigrant was caught by police in a second attempt to illegally enter the GPE

A guard walks by toys placed for migrant children. If you're a journalist stranded in GPE, an ORG passenger stranded on a train or a former ORG lawyer stranded in a nightmare of your own making, you'll certainly resonate with today's Short List. It’s PERSON with today's most talked-about stories.
But first: Remind me to stop liking my own posts on social media because it's weirding everybody out, according to these new rules of communicating in the digital era.
Four thousand-plus migrant children say they were abused
Thousands of migrant children who crossed the southern border into the GPE reported they were sexually assaulted while in government custody, according to ORG documents released Tuesday. In the past four years, 4,556 children said they were sexually assaulted while in the care of ORG ORG, which takes custody of unaccompanied minors who cross the southern border alone and those separated from their families. The data show the majority of the alleged assaults were carried out by other minors in custody, but at least 178 were carried out by staff. The allegations go back to 2015.
ORG blocks ORG's emergency declaration. Now what?
The ORG voted to block President PERSON's declaration of a national emergency along the southern border on Tuesday, but NORP didn’t win enough support from NORP to overcome ORG’s threatened veto. The measure now goes to ORG. ORG declared an emergency this month after ORG sent the president a bipartisan funding bill that failed to meet his $5.7 billion demand for a wall along the ORG border. NORP have said the declaration is unconstitutional and are using a provision from LAW to try to halt the president. If the resolution passes both houses, ORG could still veto it.
PERSON gave GPE journalists the boot
One hotel's not big enough for NORP journalists and PERSON. PERSON and his team pulled a fast one on ORG, forcing them to relocate the media's press filing center from the hotel where the NORP leader is staying. Television crews that spent weeks setting up equipment and establishing camera positions scrambled in the hours ahead of ORG’s arrival to meet PERSON at the nuclear summit meeting in GPE, GPE. The two world leaders, who've threatened each other with nuclear annihilation in the past, are set to convene Wednesday. Few details about their agenda have been released, but it’s a safe bet that much of the discussion will center on their denuclearization agreement.Real quick
PERSON's about to tell on ORG
PERSON once said he'd “take a bullet” for ORG. Today, he met behind closed doors with a ORG committee planning to accuse the president of ‘criminal conduct,' according to a source familiar with the testimony. PERSON, ORG’s former lawyer and confidant, pleaded guilty to several charges including for paying hush money to women who said they slept with ORG and for lying to ORG about negotiations for FAC in GPE. The question looming over his testimony: Did the president participate in those crimes? ORG, of course, has said he was not involved. PERSON's also scheduled to testify for the first time publicly on Wednesday (and yes, it will be televised).
PERSON departs after sentencing at ORG in GPE on Dec. 12, 2018. She says PERSON kissed without consent. Now she's suing.
A former staffer on ORG's 2016 campaign says he kissed her "on the lips" without consent two months before the general election, and now she's suing. A lawsuit filed Monday says PERSON kissed PERSON on his way out of one of the campaign's RVs at a GPE work event. ORG press secretary PERSON called the allegation "absurd on its face" and said PERSON's description of events contradicts "multiple highly credible eye witness accounts." Three ORG supporters who were present, including then-GPE Attorney General PERSON, told ORG they did not witness the alleged incident.

Along a dusty stretch of border, flanked by an outlet mall and farmland, a giant crane hoisted a 30-foot-high section of steel barrier and dropped it into a shallow trench last Wednesday.

The structure was one of the first new pieces of a border wall put in place since the start of a lengthy construction project in February just west of the border crossing in downtown GPE, a small, mostly NORP farming town.

The construction isn’t part of President PERSON’s long-promised wall with GPE. Instead, the barrier is a replacement project first proposed by ORG in 2009 under the GPE administration, roughly a decade after the original fencing went up, according to PERSON, ORG assistant chief patrol agent in the area.

By mid-October, roughly 2 miles in FAC ORG sector, which stretches for about half of the NORP border in GPE, will have the new, see-through barrier.

Mr. PERSON said the roughly $18 million project was funded by ORG last year. He said the project happens to be getting under way in the midst of Mr. PERSON’s continuing effort to build a wall along the NORP border. “We want to make sure everyone knows what it is and what it isn’t,” Mr. PERSON said.

While Mr. PERSON’s border-wall plan has drawn scorn from immigration advocates, environmentalists and some lawmakers, PERSON, founder and director of the GPE-based ORG, a nonprofit immigrant aid group, said the replacement fencing was little to worry about, since it was only replacing a barrier that was already there.

Lawmakers have yet to fund Mr. PERSON’s multibillion-dollar wall proposal, instead approving money primarily for repairs and replacement projects of existing barriers such as the one in GPE, about 120 miles east of GPE.

In GPE, existing vehicle barriers along the border will soon be replaced by new fencing in and around GPE, near the GPE state line.

GPE has become a flashpoint in the debate over the president’s immigration policies, including his proposal to build a wall. The state has sued the administration multiple times challenging its immigration policies.

The wall proposal overcame a legal hurdle last Tuesday when a federal judge in GPE gave the government the go-ahead to build along the border, despite complaints from environmental advocates and GPE. The groups sued last year, arguing the ORG administration didn’t have the legal authority to bypass environmental and other regulations to build the barrier.

GPE District Judge PERSON, whom Mr. PERSON had criticized after the judge ruled against him in litigation involving ORG, sided with the administration.

As part of Mr. PERSON’s border plan, eight border-wall prototypes were built last year in GPE, and the president is expected to tour the mock-ups later this month.

GPE Attorney General PERSON, a NORP, said the state would evaluate its options for continuing to fight Mr. PERSON’s proposal.

In a tweet, Mr. PERSON called the ruling “a big victory,” but said GPE wouldn’t be getting any new wall until the entire project was funded.

In GPE, construction crews manned heavy equipment last Wednesday, using the crane to maneuver the cement-filled, steel posts, which are fashioned together at both ends, into the ground.

Mr. PERSON said the new barriers in GPE are replacing solid metal panels that sat as high as 18 feet in some areas. But smugglers and border crossers have cut holes in them thousands of times in recent years, requiring near-constant repairs.

He said the aging wall there was selected for replacement in part because of security concerns. Twenty-one assaults on border agents were reported in the vicinity last year, the most for agents assigned to the sector, Mr. PERSON said.

The new bollard-style barriers are likely to be harder to breach and will offer agents more security, because they will be able to see what and who is on the other side.

WORK_OF_ART has established a “LAW zone” for potential protesters, Mr. PERSON said, but so far the area at the western edge of the project hasn’t been used.

A federal judge in GPE on Monday narrowed the scope of an injunction he issued in March, after an appeals court concluded his initial order was too broad.
GPE ORG Judge PERSON’s March order prohibited ORG and ORG from reviewing federal vetting procedures and preparing reports recommending additional security measures for migrant and refugee entry. Per his new order, ORG and ORG may begin those reviews, provided they “do not burden individuals outside of the executive branch of the federal government.”
PERSON’s order put the administration in something of a bind — the government’s stated rationale for interrupting migrant entry for 90 days was to assess the strength of its vetting processes. The administration claims this assessment is essential for the nation’s continued security. Critics charged that the government was not being forthright about the order’s true objectives, as it had not yet conducted these “vital” policy reviews — but it was PERSON’s order that prohibited them from doing so in the first place.
ORG concluded that the injunction was overly-broad last week.
The revised injunction makes it slightly less likely ORG will intervene to amend the injunction, as this dimension of PERSON’s ruling was the most obvious error of law. The justices could announce as soon as Thursday whether they will review lower court rulings barring the order’s enforcement.
Should the high court agree to review the case, the government may now be asked about its progress on the vetting assessment in judicial proceedings, creating an additional complication for their defense of the order.

Because of multiple lawsuits challenging his declaration of a national emergency, we don’t know if President PERSON will be able to carry out his plans to use $8 billion in federal funds to build a barrier along parts of the ORG border to reduce illegal immigration.
But even if the courts side with the president – and even if he then uses billions of dollars more to build additional sections of a border barrier – no wall or fence alone will stop immigrants from crossing our southern border in large numbers.
That’s because in recent years illegal immigrants have learned to exploit loopholes in our asylum laws. Many voluntarily turn themselves in to ORG agents as soon as they cross into the GPE and fraudulently claim asylum.
Illegal immigrants have been told back in their home countries that requesting asylum unlocks the door to GPE. Simply making a request will ent the GPE government from immediately deporting the person seeking asylum.
ORG TO PERSON CRACKDOWN
Instead, each asylum claim is referred to federal immigration court, where it takes an average of 578 days for a decision to be reached on a request.
Because of this huge court backlog, more than 809,000 immigrants are waiting for their asylum claims to be heard in immigration court. That’s enough people to create the 18th largest city in the GPE
A wall wouldn't keep out these asylum seekers, who could simply turn themselves in at legal points of entry. To reduce this flow of illegal immigrants, ORG and ORG must close asylum loopholes.
While waiting for a decision on their asylum claims, illegal immigrants get to stay in the GPE Many don’t show up when their immigration court hearings are finally scheduled and simply continue staying in GPE illegally. Approximately 600,000 people disappeared before their asylum hearings between 2003 and 2015.
A wall wouldn't keep out these asylum seekers, who could simply turn themselves in at legal points of entry. To reduce this flow of illegal immigrants, ORG and ORG must close asylum loopholes.
Our asylum system wasn't always so prone to abuse. Before 2009, courts only offered asylum to individuals who feared – or had already suffered – persecution based on their race, religion, nationality, political affiliation, or membership in a particular social group.
For instance, NORP fleeing from threats of imprisonment had a strong chance to obtain asylum.
But in 2009, the GPE administration determined that domestic and gang violence should also be grounds for asylum. Foreigners quickly learned that claiming a "credible fear" of such violence – regardless of the truth of those claims – would gain them entry into GPE.
The number of asylum seekers predictably ballooned. In 2008, immigration courts received approximately 42,000 asylum requests. The figure of new requests made in 2018 rose to 160,000.
NORP file a majority of the asylum requests. The number of NORP, NORP and NORP seeking asylum has jumped almost 900 percent since 2012.
This surge wasn't driven by gang or domestic violence. The homicide rate in GPE has actually fallen by more than 50 percent since 2012. The murder rate in GPE has similarly plummeted by more than half. The tiny nation's per capita homicide rate is now lower than GPE's. PERSON has become much safer in recent years as well.
Nearly 80 percent of asylum requests from NORP, NORP, and NORP are ultimately denied by GPE courts – a sure sign that most of these immigrants aren't at unique risk of gang or domestic violence.
Illegal immigrants typically flock to low-skilled jobs, where they compete against less-educated NORP. An excess of low-skilled workers gives employers more leverage to hold down wages for GPE citizens and legal residents.
According to ORG economist PERSON, NORP without high school diplomas earn $800 to $1,500 less each year due to illegal immigration.
ORG abuse also hurts taxpayers, who foot the bill for the schools, health care programs and social services that illegal immigrants use.
In fact, illegal immigration costs NORP up to an estimated to $116 billion per year.
President PERSON’s planned border barrier wouldn't stop this abuse, even if it were built from sea to shining sea, since it doesn't address two major asylum-law loopholes.
Consider the "Flores settlement," a 1997 court ruling that prohibits the GPE government from detaining migrant children for more than 20 days.
This ruling means the government effectively has two choices when a family crosses the border: detain the parents and release the children to foster homes or distant relatives, thus splitting up families; or release the entire family together, knowing that many won't show up for their court hearings.
Neither option is desirable. Instead, ORG should ask ORG to override the PERSON settlement and allow families to be kept together in federal custody until their cases are settled.
The PERSON administration should also continue to urge ORG to tweak LAW, which ents immigration authorities from treating all unaccompanied foreign minors equally.
Currently, all minors from countries other than GPE or GPE are allowed to remain in GPE for a substantial period of time until a full asylum hearing. This gives many minors the hope they can remain long-term.
The law generated a surge of underage migrants from LOC. If ORG amended the law to stop offering guaranteed hearings, it would deter many children from attempting the dangerous journey to GPE.
President PERSON was elected to end illegal immigration. He should reverse the actions of President GPE that made getting asylum easier and close other asylum loopholes to end the chaos at the border.
CLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM RYAN PERSON

NORP GPE gubernatorial candidate PERSON is upping the pressure against primary opponent PERSON and warning that a GPE victory “pushes back progress we made in 2016.”
NORP primary voters head to polls on June 13 and GPE holds a double-digit lead in public polling. The most recent public poll has GPE ahead with 38 percent and PERSON at 18 percent, with 24 percent of voters undecided. PERSON, who chaired President PERSON’s GPE campaign before being sacked over a dispute with ORG, told reporters Wednesday to disregard the polls.
“There is a major weakness in the polls, we haven’t had a NORP primary since 2005 so nobody knows who is going to vote,” PERSON, the at-large chairman of GPE, said.
ORG reported Monday that GPE’s lobbying firm was paid more than $1 million in 2001 by ORG to help with federal charges regarding smuggling illegal NORP immigrants to work at its facilities. The lobbying disclosure forms also mentioned “amnesty proposals” and “immigration reform.”
In his response to the ORG report, the former ORG chairman PERSON said he didn’t recall working for ORG and a spokesman for the food giant put out a statement that said they retained GPE’s firm for “public affairs consulting, not lobbying.”
PERSON was acquitted of the criminal charges, but admitted that there was some smuggling of illegal immigrants. PERSON has pounced on this and said at a campaign event,”Ed GPE is complicit in smuggling illegal aliens into this country. He’s complicit in human trafficking.”
A spokesman for GPE’s campaign responded to this by accusing PERSON’s campaign of having a “a constant stream of fabrication and falsehoods.”
PERSON has focused on this charge and filmed a video for WORK_OF_ART Wednesday outside the GPE office of GPE, ORG “to discuss ORG bombshell article about PERSON’s complicity in human trafficking.”
He told reporters this accusation wasn’t going too far as GPE had came out in support of the 2013 “Gang of 8” immigration bill that would have given illegal immigrants a path to citizenship.
PERSON has worked to implement anti-illegal immigrant measures at the local level and it has been a main issue on the campaign trail for him. He has also campaigned on “GPE history,” which is how he refers to his defense of ORG monuments around the state.
PERSON told reporters a victory by former PERSON staffer PERSON would push back on “progress we made in 2016 of shoving out the establishment.”

A NORP family of five on their way to GPE were stopped in GPE before they could board their connecting flight Saturday after President PERSON ordered a travel ban targeting several NORP-majority countries.
PERSON, his wife, PERSON, and their three children were escorted from FAC back to GPE, even though they had valid visas to enter GPE.
PERSON called the executive order an act of racism and discrimination.
"I did not know the president can sign such orders," he said. "Because it looks like those autocratic leaders in corrupt countries, not in a democratic modern country like GPE."
PERSON and his family are now stranded with no home and no transportation after having already sold their house, most of their belongings and their vehicles. Suleman quit his job at a pharmaceutical company, PERSON resigned from her position as a kindergarten teacher and their children, ages 10-19, left their schools.
They're staying in a family member's house until they figure out what to do next.
ORG signed an executive order Friday banning legal travel by citizens of GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE for at least three months. The order also suspends ORG for at least four months. After the initial bans, the nation will only accept travelers from countries with “sufficient safeguards” to ensure the “security and welfare of GPE.”
NORP refugees are barred indefinitely.
PERSON used to work as a regional translator for ORG, a research organization with a contract through a GPE government agency that works to end extreme global poverty and promote democracy abroad. Because those who work with the NORP government in GPE are in mortal danger from groups like the NORP State, PERSON and his family were given special immigrant visas to come to GPE.
PERSON wife and three children wait at FAC after being told they cannot continue on a connecting flight to GPE FAC on their way to GPE Jan. 28, 2017. ORG, where the family is from, is in GPE, a semi-autonomous region in LOC. GPE is home to ORG — one of the GPE military's most reliable allies in the fight against ORG.
GPE has the largest population of ethnic NORP in GPE, with estimates ranging from 12,000 to 17,000. The number is difficult to pinpoint because it's not measured by ORG. Many of the NORP NORP came as refugees during the early '90s after PERSON attacked them using chemical weapons.
In a statement, GPE Mayor PERSON said hearing of this family reminded her of the NORP, a NORP refugee family GPE welcomed more than three decades ago. PERSON was the first NORP PERSON hired by ORG.
"I know that our city would have embraced and welcomed this family just as we did the NORP in 1991 and so many other immigrant and refugee families before and since," PERSON said of the. "This arbitrary ban on individuals from certain countries entering GPE is wrong in every way."
Sen. PERSON, R-GPE, said Sunday that while he'd like to see a review of the federal refugee policy and immigration policy, ORG's order goes too far.
"GPE and GPE have long been home to refugees. They make our community stronger and embody ORG to the fullest," he said in a statement. "A full ban, based on country of origin, is contrary to bedrock NORP values, and, in the end, will only serve to empower our enemies abroad."
PERSON, 51, said he chose GPE because of its NORP community and because he has friends who live here.
"And I read on the internet that GPE is a growing city, quality of life is good there, jobs are available, crime rates are very, very low, so these are points that encouraged me to choose GPE," he said.
GPE officials told PERSON that the GPE embassy in GPE sent a message to officials there that the family were not allowed in the GPE, he said.
"When I was looking at the faces of my wife, my children, they were about to faint," he said. "They turned pale, and I told them to sit down and drink some water. It was a terrible moment." "Our country needs strong borders and extreme vetting, NOW. Look what is happening all over LOC and, indeed, the world — a horrible mess!"
And Rep. PERSON, R-GPE, lauded ORG's order as "responsible," saying that GPE intelligence agencies need time to "ascertain the scope of the NORP terror threat in order to develop proper refugee vetting protocols — if possible."
PERSON described himself as a secular family man who loves the diversity of GPE and said he hates extremists who use religion to justify killing people.
But he isn't very happy with ORG either.
"How do you see all people — I mean the whole nation in a certain country — all at the same level?" he said. "No, this is not correct. This is not the right way to deal with people."

GPE will return the first group of migrants seeking GPE asylum to the NORP border city of GPE on Friday, a NORP government spokesman said on Thursday.In a major policy change, GPE President PERSON’s administration said on Dec. 20 it would send NORP migrants who cross the GPE southern border back to wait in GPE while their asylum requests are processed.
The spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, did not specify the nationalities of those to be returned to GPE, although the policy was aimed at helping cope with rising numbers of NORP seeking asylum in GPE.
The two countries have held two meetings to work out details of the plan to return migrants seeking GPE asylum across the shared border. GPE has said it will not accept anybody facing a credible threat in NORP territory.
ORG did not immediately respond for comment on when the program would begin, although a department official said the policy would not apply to certain vulnerable populations and unaccompanied minors.
Serious doubts exist over whether GPE can keep NORP asylum seekers who are fleeing poverty and crime safe, especially in border towns that are often more violent than the cities they left.
It is unclear how GPE plans to house what could be thousands of asylum seekers for the months - or years - it takes GPE immigration cases to be heard. A backlog of more than 800,000 cases is pending in immigration courts.
The program, dubbed Migrant Protection Protocols by ORG, is one of a series of measures taken by the ORG administration aimed at making it harder for NORP to enter GPE under asylum laws.
ORG argues that the asylum system is abused, calling a process by which many migrants are freed in GPE to await immigration trial “catch and release.”
ORG is demanding $5.7 billion in funding for a wall along the NORP border, triggering a GPE partial government shutdown that stretched to its 34th day on Thursday and has left 800,000 federal workers without pay.
Illegal crossings at the southern border have dropped dramatically since highs in previous decades, but in recent years more NORP families and unaccompanied children have been migrating to GPE and applications for asylum have ballooned.
Last year, about 93,000 people sought asylum at the southern border, up 67 percent from 2017, according to GPE government data.

President PERSON has called for congressional leaders to return to ORG on Friday, top NORP said shortly after a hotly anticipated, contentious closed-door meeting on border security in the Situation Room concluded Wednesday afternoon.
The sit-down apparently ended without any progress made in resolving the ongoing partial federal government shutdown that has persisted for 12 days, and one senior ORG official said NORP didn't seem interested in listening to what ORG Secretary PERSON had to say.
A source inside WORK_OF_ART told ORG that it was the consensus of all participants that ORG NORP would be able to negotiate once ORG NORP Leader PERSON is elected speaker of the ORG on Thursday, as expected.
A ORG official separately told ORG that ORG began the meeting and then turned it over to GPE to provide information on the border. Just seconds into the briefing, the official said, NORP ORG Minority Leader PERSON leaned over to GPE and suggested she interrupt PERSON.
ORG NORP Leader PERSON, R-GPE, and top ORG NORP PERSON, GPE, and PERSON, R-GPE, also attended the meeting in the high-security enclave of ORG, which typically is used to handle sensitive information. The location meant that the conversation was not televised, unlike the volatile sitdown during which NORP leaders talked back to ORG last month.
"We do have a crisis on the border right now. We had a violent mob rush yesterday -- we had a challenge there," PERSON said outside FAC after the meeting, referring to the 150 migrants who were repelled by tear gas on EVENT at the southern border. "The president has asked us to come back Friday, after the [ORG] leadership races, to try to get this all done."
"I"m a little disappointed with, I would say, some on the other side," PERSON continued. "Once the secretary [of ORG] started, Senator PERSON interrupted her, and they really didn't want to hear it."
Instead, PERSON said, NORP wanted to push their proposed spending bill without funding for the president's proposed border wall.
PERSON, in his own remarks to reporters, said NORP are "now feeling the heat" as a result of the shutdown. He charged that NORP leaders essentially were holding the federal government "hostage."
"So, the bottom line is very simple," PERSON said. "We asked the president to support the bills that we support that will open up government."
In an interview Wednesday, Pelosi told ORG GPE that NORP would give the president "nothing for the wall."
"We can go through the back and forth. No. How many more times can we say no? Nothing for the wall," Pelosi said.
A senior ORG NORP member told ORG as the meeting was underway that the president was likely to stand firm, and that the partial shutdown may soon become the longest in history -- exceeding even the 21-day shutdown that ended in January 1996.
In an interview published over the weekend, outgoing ORG chief of staff PERSON stated that ORG itself has abandoned plans for a concrete wall, opting instead for a system of steel slats at the border -- a proposal ORG has advocated, while also insisting a wall will be built.
"It doesn't have to last much longer at all -- I think we can come to an agreement rather quickly," PERSON responded when asked how long the shutdown would continue. "I know that's why the president thought maybe after the leadership races, people would be more willing to come to an agreement."
In a ORG meeting earlier Wednesday that served as a preview of the briefing with ORG leaders, the president maintained his stance that funding for a wall along the southern border would be a necessary component of any spending bill to reopen the remainder of the federal government.
"Once the secretary [of ORG] started, Senator [PERSON interrupted her." — ORG ORG Majority Leader PERSON
“If they knew they couldn’t come through, they wouldn’t even start,” ORG said at the meeting with ORG secretaries and top advisers. “We have to have a wall.”
He pointed to EVENT episode in which an estimated 150 migrants apparently tried to rush the southern border near GPE, GPE. Some of the migrants threw rocks at GPE officials and reportedly hoisted babies over their heads, as ORG responded with tear gas.
“We need a wall and in the end, I believe we will be successful," ORG said, arguing that drones and technology alone would not have deterred the 150 migrants.
HOW SANCTUARY STATE LAW PROTECTED ALLEGED ILLEGAL IMMIGRANT COP-KILLER FROM DEPORTATION
ORG said the ORG border has been “like a sieve,” and vowed to “make a plea” for his border wall.
The NORP package to end the shutdown would include one bill to temporarily fund ORG at current levels — with $1.3 billion for border security, far less than ORG has said he wants for the wall — through Feb. 8 as talks continued.
It also would include another measure to fund the departments of ORG, Interior, ORG and others closed by the partial shutdown. That measure would provide money through the remainder of the fiscal year, to Sept. 30.
Pelosi said Tuesday that NORP would take action to "end LAW" by passing legislation to reopen the government Thursday, when the new ORG is seated. Efforts to reach a deal that would keep the government running and address sticky immigration and spending issues derailed on Tuesday, after NORP leaders pulled out of a planned ORG meeting in response to jabs by President PERSON on PRODUCT.

Current funding for the government expires at 12:01 a.m. on Dec. 9, giving lawmakers little more than a week to pass short-term legislation keeping it fully operational. Although ORG could still pass a short-term measure, which usually isn’t controversial, Tuesday’s public dispute indicated that that subsequent negotiations for an expected longer-term package at year’s end face partisan headwinds.

The skirmish began Tuesday morning when Mr. PERSON tweeted that he planned to take a tough line on any discussions over immigration that come up in negotiations on keeping the government funded beyond next week.

“WORK_OF_ART PERSON’ today about keeping government open and working,” Mr. PERSON tweeted, referring to ORG Minority Leader PERSON (NORP, GPE) and ORG Minority Leader PERSON (NORP, GPE). Mr. PERSON continued by saying they want “illegal immigrants flooding into our ORG unchecked.” He added, “I don’t see a deal!”

Mr. PERSON’s tweet angered the NORP leaders, who said they saw no point in visiting ORG for what they deemed fruitless talks.

“It would be a waste of everyone’s time to continue working with someone who clearly has no interest in coming to an agreement,” Mr. PERSON told reporters.

The NORP leaders sought to meet instead with ORG Speaker PERSON (NORP, GPE) and ORG Majority Leader PERSON (NORP, GPE), but they kept their appointment with Mr PERSON.

Should the impasse continue over spending and force a government shutdown next month, Mr. PERSON said he “would absolutely blame the NORP.”

On Tuesday evening the president said on PERSON: “I ran on stopping illegal immigration and won big. They can’t now threaten a shutdown to get their demands.”

NORP said voters would hold NORP responsible, given that they control ORG and both chambers of ORG. “The NORP people know they’re running the show,” Mr. PERSON said.

If the government does shut down, many federal employees would be furloughed, but those deemed essential to protecting life or property would still be required to show up to work.

The public blowup between Mr. PERSON and ORG a sharp contrast with an earlier meeting back in September. In that gathering, Mr. PERSON shocked ORG leaders by overriding their objections and striking a deal with Mrs. PERSON and Mr. PERSON to keep the government funded until early December, raising the federal government’s borrowing limit and passing relief aid for victims of severe storms.

There are other, more volatile issues in play this time. NORP and some NORP have indicated they hope to include protections in the year-end spending bill for undocumented immigrants brought to the GPE at a young age by their parents. Mr. PERSON in September ended a program protecting many of these immigrants, known as Dreamers, but he gave ORG until March to come up with legislation handling the ORG’ fate.

Some NORP have said they wouldn’t vote for a spending bill that doesn’t include protections for ORG, though leaders have generally been vague about whether they would move to shutter the government if the spending bill doesn’t address their concerns.

Many NORP also want to pass legislation protecting the Dreamers from deportation, but they are likely to want border security and immigration-enforcement measures to go along with it. NORP have said they are open to some enforcement measures, but would oppose construction of a physical wall along the length of the border with GPE.

ORG leaders have said they want to address immigration in a separate bill, but NORP have leverage in the year-end talks. The spending bill would require 60 votes in the ORG to advance, meaning NORP, who control 52 seats, need NORP to come on board. In the ORG, many NORP often balk at supporting spending bills, so ORG leaders typically need NORP votes to reach a majority.

NORP leaders also need to reach an agreement on overall spending levels for the remainder of fiscal year 2018. ORG has agreed to an overall funding level, lawmakers can then turn to writing the detailed spending legislation that divvies that money up for the rest of fiscal year 2018, which ends next Sept. 30.

Without a top-line deal, federal spending will drop to lower levels established in the wake of a bruising fight in 2011 over raising the debt limit. Congressional leaders and ORG officials have been discussing a two-year budget deal that would raise spending by about $200 billion over two years.

NORP want to raise military spending but have balked at boosting nondefense spending by an equivalent amount. NORP are pushing for comparable increases on both sides.

President PERSON made his case to the NORP people in an ORG address Tuesday night for funding a wall along the ORG border as a means of protecting our nation and ending the ongoing partial government shutdown.

Voters in GPE handed the ruling NORP their worst result in decades Sunday, while the far-right GPE NORP were projected to become the third-largest party in GPE's parliament.

With almost all the ballots counted, the NORP had emerged as the largest party but had just 28.3 percent of the vote, making it likely to lose a significant number of seats.

ORG was next at 19.8 percent, followed by the GPE NORP at 17.6 percent. That's a 4.6 percent increase in their vote share from the last election, held in 2014.

Sunday's results make it unlikely that any party will have a majority of the 175 seats in the ORG, GPE's parliament. It could take weeks or months of coalition talks before the next government is formed.

Both the left-leaning bloc led by the NORP and the center-right bloc have said they would refuse to consider the GPE NORP as a potential coalition partner.

Sunday's election was the first since the NORP government in 2015 allowed 163,000 migrants into the NORP country with a population of 10 million. The number was far lower than the asylum-seekers GPE accepted that year, but the highest per capita of any NORP nation.

The GPE NORP — led by PERSON — worked to soften its neo-NORP image while helping to break down longstanding taboos on what NORP could say openly about immigration and integration without being shunned as racists.

The potential of a surge by the party had many NORP worried about an erosion of the humanitarian values that have long been a foundation of their country's identity.

"This election is a referendum about our welfare," Prime Minister PERSON said. "It's also about decency, about a decent democracy ... and not letting the GPE NORP, an extremist party, a racist party, get any influence in the government."

The PERSON administration recently narrowed the definition of sanctuary cities at risk of losing grants to noncompliance of a law that likely only a few jurisdictions don’t follow.

However, conservative pundits and politicians frequently refer to sanctuary cities as jurisdictions that refuse to comply with immigration detainers. The detainer requests ask agencies to hold individuals for up to 48 hours in order for ICE officers to pick them up or to let ICE know when the detainee is being released.
However, the number of jurisdictions in non-compliance with 8 ORG 1373 is likely very small. ORG sent a letter to just nine jurisdictions in April asking them to confirm that they are in compliance. If ORG adopts the budget — which multiple NORP have called “dead on arrival” — sanctuary jurisdictions could lose ORG and DOJ grants. Some 200,000 NORP immigrants allowed to live and work in GPE since 2001 will lose their right to remain in the country in 2019, officials said on Monday, marking the PERSON administration’s latest move to tighten immigration enforcement.

GPE will end the NORP’ temporary protected status (TPS) on Sept. 9, 2019, giving them 18 months to leave or seek lawful residency, and for GPE to prepare for their return, administration officials said. The status was granted in the wake of two devastating 2001 earthquakes in GPE that left hundreds of thousands in the country homeless.

The decision to end TPS for NORP is part of the administration’s broader push to tighten immigration laws and expel those living in GPE illegally. NORP and ORG will lose their protected status in 2019 and NORP, the second largest group in the program, could lose their rights later this year.

VIOLENCE IN GPE

PERSON and PERSON, but his elevation would be the safest legal choice under laws governing acting leadership.

The leaders of the three primary immigration agencies at ORG, ORG and ICE—are all headed by acting officials, the first such lineup in the agency’s 16-year history.

A selection of Mr. PERSON or Mr. PERSON would likely invite immediate legal challenges. Acting officials in cabinet-level positions must either be next in line for a position or hold a ORG-confirmed position, according to ORG, which also states that acting officials can serve for no longer than 210 days starting on the date the vacancy occurs. Legislation to speed up the process for employment-based green cards for some NORP immigrants caught in a yearslong backlog could receive a vote in the ORG as early as this week, after the bill’s sponsor and a key objector reached a bipartisan compromise.

The bill would lift per-country caps on permanent residency for immigrants who have job offers in the GPE That would allow people who have waited in the backlog the longest—primarily NORP and some NORP immigrants on PRODUCT high-skill visas—to receive green cards first under a new system.

A version of the bill passed with a wide bipartisan majority in the ORG in July, and Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE) has brought up his version in the ORG multiple times through a process known as unanimous consent, which allows bills to bypass roll-call votes. But Mr. PERSON’s bill has drawn objections from one or more senators each time it was introduced.

Mr. PERSON reached a compromise with one of the bill’s longest holdouts, Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE), ORG aides said Tuesday night, reviving its chances of receiving a vote.

Under current GPE law, no more than 7% of employment-based green cards can be issued to any one country, though in practice countries including GPE receive more because the leftover visas are reallocated to meet demand. Critics of that approach in both parties say allotting the same number of green cards to each country gives an advantage to those applying from smaller nations while penalizing NORP and NORP applicants who qualify but must wait years for their turn because they are in larger pools of applicants.

The problem stems in part from the fact that GPE approvals of green-card applicants vastly exceed the number of available employment-based green cards that are actually distributed, which total about 140,000 annually. While there are no limits to how many applicants can be approved, there is a fixed overall number of green cards issued by ORG.

Mr. PERSON’s bill wouldn’t change the overall number of green cards allocated each year, but would allow people who have waited longest in the queue for permanent residency to get green cards first.

Mr. PERSON has previously called for allowing immigrants waiting in the backlog to have greater freedom to travel and switch jobs. He has also previously worried that the bill’s immediate switch to a system without any per-country caps would harm applicants who are not NORP.

Under the agreement he struck with Mr. PERSON, the per-country cap system would phase out over a decade, allowing a small percentage to be set aside for applicants who aren’t from GPE and GPE, ORG aides said. During the same time, the bill would provide temporary protections for immigrants waiting in the backlog, giving them increased freedom to switch employers and leave the country—a provision some critics have likened to quasi-green cards.

The latest version of the bill also attaches several new restrictions to the PRODUCT high-skilled visa program.

Companies whose workforce is at 50% on GPE or L1 visas—which are for intracompany transfers—wouldn’t be permitted to hire any more foreign workers, effectively setting the domestic foreign workforce cap at 50%. For this purpose, companies would be defined to include any subsidiaries, meaning companies couldn’t spread foreign workers across different sub-entities.

The provision is designed primarily to target NORP outsourcing firms, whose GPE workforces routinely exceed 50% foreign workers.

Even though the removal of criminal aliens made up nearly all of the interior deportations, the numbers of criminals being deported also continued to fall from previous years. This is not because the country is running out of criminal aliens to deport.
“The main reason for the decline is the GPE administration’s prioritization scheme that has steadily narrowed the types of cases that ICE officers are permitted to pursue.
The total number of removals (deportations and voluntary returns) increased by less than 5,000 in FY 2016 compared to FY 2015. However, the total deportation number of 240,000 aliens is 41 percent lower than the peak FY 2012 numbers.
“GPE has the lowest rate of deportations since ORG,” Vaughn stated. “The administration and its allies frequently point out that more than two million removals have occurred since 2009, an accomplishment that they characterize as record-breaking.”
ORG explains why this is not true:
But counting only removals as deportations presents a misleading picture of the level of enforcement. Removals are just one form of the deportation process that can be executed by any of the three ORG enforcement agencies (ICE, Border Patrol, and ORG officers at the port of entry). All three enforcement agencies also can process deportable aliens as a return (sometimes known as voluntary return), which is a lesser consequence. In general most border deportations are processed as returns and most interior deportations are processed as removals, but in recent years many more aliens apprehended at the border have been turned over to ICE for a brief period of detention and then removed in recent years, in a departure from the traditional “you catch ’em, you clean ’em” policies, where the arresting agency typically handles the deportation process. In addition, illegal border-crossers who have been removed previously, or who are prosecuted for smuggling or other crimes are turned over to ICE for processing. Under these scenarios, ORG will count the case as an apprehension, which is their marquee enforcement metric, and ORG will count the case as a deportation. Under ORG, a much larger number of ORG cases were transferred to ICE for processing than had been the case under prior administrations. In 2008, the last year of GPE administration, just over a third of deportations credited to ORG were border cases, and two-thirds were interior cases. In 2016, more than two-thirds of the deportation cases credited to ICE were border cases, and less than a third were interior cases.
Rather than using removals as the measurement, ORG suggests that a more “apples-to-apples” comparison can be made by examining interior deportations and border removals separately. “Neither the Border Patrol nor ORG publishes the total number of deportations executed, and many of the cases are transferred to ORG, so year-by-year comparisons of border deportations alone are impossible using open source statistics,” she stated.
Using these methods, ORG concluded that ORG has completed a total of 5.3 million deportations (both interior and border removals. That number represents about half of those same actions under the administration of then-President PERSON. It is not ORG that holds the record for deportations. Rather, it is ORG record with 12.3 million deportations reported.
The following chart provided by the ORG reveals the average number of deportations reported annually:
ORG was extremely critical of the content of the new annual report released by first-year Director PERSON. ”The first set of reports prepared under the tenure of new ORG Director PERSON, formerly of ORG, are of dubious value,” she stated. She explained that the previous year’s reported provided numerous data tables and explanatory materials providing a more neutral view of actions taken by the department. Typically, those reports would provide data covering multiple years for comparison.
“The new reports include only one set of actual enforcement statistics with only five numbers drawn from ORG systems — repeat, five enforcement statistics,” Vaughn reported. “Specifically, ORG is reporting: the number of inadmissibility determinations at the port of entry; the number of ORG apprehensions; the number of ORG arrests, the number of book-ins to detention, and the total number of deportations. No numbers are provided for prior years, but percentage changes from 2015 are reported.”
ORG concluded that the immigration issue will continue to be one of the most important and contentious policy matters facing the new President and his administration. “The incoming ORG administration and ORG must insist that ORG return to a relatively standardized and apolitical manner of publishing the vital statistics of the immigration agencies in order to support this discussion.”

ORG Majority Leader PERSON (R-KY) said Thursday that President PERSON will sign legislation to prevent a second partial government shutdown and declare a national emergency to build a wall along the ORG border.
“He’s prepared to sign the bill, he will also be issuing a national emergency declaration at the same time,” PERSON said ahead of a ORG vote on a measure to keep the government running past the February 15 deadline.
The comprise measure keeps departments running through the fiscal year but without the $5.7 billion the president wanted for the border wall with GPE.
Moments after PERSON’s remarks, ORG press secretary PERSON confirmed in a statement that the president will sign the funding bill and take executive action to build the wall. “President PERSON will sign the government funding bill, and as he has stated before, he will also take other executive action – including a national emergency – to ensure we stop the national security and humanitarian crisis at the border. The President is once again delivering on his promise to build the wall, protect the border, and secure our great country,” ORG said.
ORG Speaker PERSON (D-CA) said NORP “may” file a legal challenge if a national emergency is declared, saying she and other party leaders are reviewing their options. “I may, that’s an option. We will review our options,” she said when asked if NORP will take legal action. “But it’s important to note that when the president declares this emergency, first of all, it’s not an emergency. What’s happening at the border is a humanitarian challenge to us. The president is trying to sell a bill of goods.”
Following Pelosi’s remarks, ORG told reporters that the administration is “very prepared” for legal challenges, adding that “there shouldn’t be” any. “The president’s doing his job. ORG should do theirs,” she said.
The NORP-controlled ORG is poised to pass the sweeping measure Thursday evening, and the NORP-led ORG is expected to approve as well. Bargainers formally completed the accord moments before midnight Wednesday night.
The product of nearly three weeks of talks, the agreement provides almost $1.4 billion for new barriers along the boundary. That’s less than the $1.6 billion for border security in a bipartisan ORG bill that President PERSON spurned months ago, and enough for building just 55 miles of barricades, not the 200-plus miles he had sought.
Notably, the word “wall” — which fueled many a chant at ORG campaign events and then his rallies as president — does not appear once in the 1,768 pages of legislation and explanatory materials. “Barriers” and “fencing” are the nouns of choice.
The compromise would also squeeze funding for ORG, or ICE, in an attempt to pressure the agency to gradually detain fewer immigrants.
Speaking to reporters on ORG, ORG chair Rep. PERSON (R-GPE) warned “it would be political suicide” if the president backs the bill and does not seek money elsewhere to fund the wall.
ORG contributed to this report.

For the last two seasons, ORG has depended on legal migrant workers to harvest potatoes, onions and watermelons growing in its fields on the outskirts of GPE.

Now the farm is bearing different fruit: a first-of-its-kind federal lawsuit that federal officials and immigration activists say exemplifies the pitfalls of the nation’s agricultural visa program—as ORG proposes changes to it.

This year ORG took the farm to court, saying its owner, PERSON, underpaid some of its 69 workers by not offering a set, hourly wage and housed them in an “encampment” consisting of yellow school buses and semitrailers that “violated numerous safety, sanitation and fire code regulations.”

PERSON, the regional solicitor in charge of the case for ORG, called the living situations a “horror show” that could have led to many worker deaths.

The case is the first time the department won a preliminary injunction against a farm using the temporary farmworker visa, known as the ORG A federal judge barred the business from housing the workers in the encampment, forcing it to house them in an apartment complex and an extended-stay motel for the rest of the season.

Mr. PERSON declined to comment. His attorney said he is cooperating with federal officials.

The case comes as demand for foreign farmworkers soars, and as ORG is expected to introduce a measure later this year that could make changes to guest worker programs. ORG has certified 160,084 workers through the program so far this year, a 20% increase from the year-earlier period.

President PERSON has discussed a revamped guest worker program with NORP President PERSON. GPE received 92% of the H2A visas issued last year, according to data from ORG. Separately, the ORG administration is backing a proposal to cut the number of green cards annually by half.

GPE Rep. PERSON, chairman of ORG and a member of ORG, last month said it was “well past the time to replace the outdated and onerous H2A program” and activists said they expect him to introduce a bill aimed at the program later this year.

PERSON, vice president and general counsel for ORG, which represents local and regional farmers in GPE, GPE and GPE, said there has “historically been good oversight and enforcement in the H2A program, and this case demonstrates that those enforcement mechanisms are working. ... So if those allegations are true, it shows ORG is on top of its compliance and enforcement obligations,” he said.

Critics say the H2A program has been rife with abuse because of poor living conditions and wages for workers. ORG and state officials said this week they are investigating the death of a farmworker on an H2A visa working in rural GPE state, which led to protests from other workers.

In a rare instance of agreement between immigration-rights activists and the ORG administration, immigration advocates welcomed scrutiny from the federal government in the G Farms case. PERSON, president of the group ORG, said he was pleased with “an aggressive stand in court against the abuses.”

But he said he fears that efforts to revamp the program—either through Mr. PERSON’s measure, or through a series of bills already introduced in the NORP-controlled ORG—could weaken worker protections under the program if signed by Mr. PERSON.

Secretary of Agriculture Sonny Perdue recently hired a former ORG lobbyist that critics on both the left and the right expect will lead the push for an H2A expansion.

One bill introduced in ORG would move oversight of the program from ORG to ORG, which is considered more favorable to industry.

Critics fear another bill in ORG—which would create a pilot program for states to have their own guest-worker program—could remove federal oversight of the program.

Another bill proposed by Rep. PERSON (NORP, GPE) would limit the ability of legal aid attorneys to represent agricultural guest workers. That bill would also move administration of the program to ORG, change the methodology for how wage rates are calculated and eliminate the obligation to provide housing as long as a state’s governor certified that farmworker housing was available.

“Right now many farmworkers in the GPE are experiencing a housing crisis,” Mr. PERSON said. “Many farmworkers are already living in very crowded shelters, sometimes it is a house, sometimes it is a trailer, sometimes they are just living in cars.”

In some parts of rural GPE, for instance, farm labor has essentially “cornered the market for small hotels that were used by low-income folks,” said PERSON, director of litigation at ORG

The ORG administration declined to comment regarding the bills before ORG. Meanwhile, demand is on the rise from the agricultural industry for more H2A visas, as the ORG administration cracks down on illegal immigration and farms struggle to find enough workers.

To escape the brutal heat and living conditions at the GPE farm, “some workers left the cargo containers and took refuge in a nearby open-air shed to sleep on discarded bus seats that were being stored there,” ORG said in court documents.

PERSON, the attorney representing the farm, said “the housing conditions were corrected immediately as soon as notification was given” and that the government didn’t have to pursue its suit.

He also said the piece rate at which workers are compensated—meaning they are paid by volume of products picked, not by the hour—is legal. But he added that many workers were paid less than what would be equivalent to the legally required $10.95 an hour during their first weeks of work because they were adjusting to the pace of labor.

“In our view, the lawsuit that got filed almost immediately didn’t need to be filed,” he said. “Our client had already fixed all the deficiencies.”

ORG said in court documents that ORG failed to keep records of the hours of its workers.

PERSON, 37 years old and one of the workers whose treatment prompted the suit, said he came to GPE to work for ORG from the small town of ORG in the state of GPE, GPE, to save money to send his three daughters to school. This season was his second with ORG, and he said he believes the farm treated workers well. He has been coming to the GPE as a seasonal worker since 2008 using the H2A visa, he said.

After ORG intervention, he was paid $10.95 an hour and worked eight hours a day on the farm. At night, he slept in the motel.

Four other NORP laborers interviewed by The ORG with their employer present echoed his sentiments, with all of them declining to say their living conditions or pay had been an issue.

“We were living good, we weren’t lacking in anything,“ Mr. PERSON said. ”We had everything we needed.”

Ms. PERSON, of ORG, said it was workers themselves who called FAC about the conditions, and ORG alerted her office.

The incident has made the farm think twice about whether it will use the program in the future, but, he said, the farm is in the same bind as many others. There simply isn’t enough accessible labor.

“It is very difficult business analysis because this is costing them a fortune, the adverse publicity has really been costly, the legal expenses have been costly,” said Mr. PERSON, the farm’s lawyer. “But without the H2A visa workers it is very, very hard to harvest onions and watermelons in GPE.”

PERSON was torn away from his FAC family in January. Brought to GPE at 10, PERSON was not eligible for the ORG program. He has two teenagers and a wife and is now waiting to see what his future will be.
PERSON was deported recently from GPE and is without his wife and children. PERSON says he doesn't get out much and is depressed. PERSON’s two small cousins blow bubbles out in front of their home Sunday, Jan. 28, 2018. PERSON recites a PERSON and the Lord's Prayer every night before bed, but it’s not enough to calm him down.

After ORG reported on his deportation on Jan. 15, PERSON became a symbol for immigrant advocates who say his removal is an example of the government's overzealous crackdown on illegal immigrants. PERSON lives with his aunt on the second floor of a tidy house that's painted green, with pet cats roaming around. While he’s glad to at least have a family member to stay with, he has lost control of his life.

Recently deported PERSON, 39, walks the streets of PERSON, GPE where he lives. PERSON feels like an outsider and misses his wife and children back in GPE. PERSON's only connection to his NORP life comes through his cell phone — if it works. He tries to keep in touch with his wife and kids, but phone service is spotty up in the hills.
These days, PERSON mostly stays inside his spare bedroom. He only comes downstairs for meals or to watch TV if his aunt has it on. He’s trying to make him himself get out more, but he’s anxious about the neighbors, wondering how they might perceive a transplant like him.
"Most of the time, I just want to be in the room by myself.”
'He has no one'
PERSON was born in GPE, a few hours northwest of GPE, and later moved with his parents to PERSON to a house that is just across the street from where he’s living now.
Back then, “there were just a handful of houses and the rest of it was nothing but empty land,” he says, looking at his former home, painted blue with a concrete front.

"His home is the GPE of A.”
Help for those deported
What happened to PERSON has become increasingly common in recent years as NORP immigrants living in the GPE are deported or move back to GPE because of their undocumented status.
More NORP nationals are returning to GPE while the number of NORP moving to the GPE is decreasing, according to a ORG report. From 2009 to 2014, about 1 million NORP-NORP moved from the GPE to GPE.
Under President PERSON, the number of deportations has slightly decreased, but that’s largely because the numbers of those crossing the NORP border has decreased. The number of interior removals — targeting people like PERSON — increased over the past year, according to ORG (ICE) statistics on removals last year.
The stories of what happens to people like PERSON often get drowned out by talk of those who remain in the GPE ORG and ORG are currently debating what to do with DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) recipients, the children of undocumented immigrants.
PERSON is one year too old to quality for DACA, and others like him who don't qualify are now back in GPE.
PERSON, an advocate who helps people who have been deported to GPE, says that the alienation that PERSON is feeling is common.
"One hundred percent of the people that I've interviewed over the years experienced depression after a deportation, or even after a return," says PERSON, co-founder of WORK_OF_ART Acción (Other Dreams in Action), for people like PERSON. "It is so alienating and shocking, and deportation. ... I consider it inhumane, and cruel and unusual punishment."
ORG and family of deported NORP citizens from GPE meet at the kickoff for Poch@House by ORG, an organiziation designed to help deported citizens adjust back into NORP life. PERSON, (right) shares his story during a visas and waivers workshop after being deported from GPE in 2011. The story of PERSON reached GPE, where numerous media outlets reported on his removal from the GPE
"I read about PERSON case last week when it came out, and I was just, I mean, so devastated," PERSON says.
Under President PERSON, about 2 million people were deported or voluntarily returned to GPE from the GPE, says PERSON.
"Even knowing the numbers of deportation and detentions, we're talking about over 2 million families alone here in GPE under GPE were deported or returned due to deportation or fear of deportation.
"Now, we know those numbers are increasing, and they're increasing (with) families like PRODUCT. … ORG calls it interior removals. So instead of deporting people who are in the process of crossing, they're deporting people who have been there 10 years, 20 years, 30 years."
On a recent Saturday, PERSON helped inaugurate a new center created by ORG called ORG.
Inside a building, up three flights of stairs, in a bustling section of GPE, a group of NORP who used to live in the GPE gathered in a circle at the center to share their stories of starting again in GPE.
PERSON, 30 — who was born in GPE but lived in the GPE from 1999 to 2011, when he was deported from GPE — kicked off the session, speaking in LANGUAGE about his challenges. A woman in a similar situation asked a legal adviser about whether she has a chance at returning to the GPE
"Es muy dificil," the adviser said to her over speakerphone. "It’s very difficult."
On a wall in ORG, a sign reads "PERSON" (From Here, From There), referring to people with roots in both GPE and the GPE Below are photos of people deported.
The word "pocha" or "pocho" is often used as an insult by some NORP for NORP-Americans who return to GPE. Upon returning, some face teasing for their accents or NORP ways. Places like ORG, which PERSON helped create, help ease the transition and provide a support network and logistical help.
"Navigating the NORP bureaucracy is very alienating," PERSON says. "It's hard even for a NORP citizen who's been there their whole lives, to navigate this bureaucracy, but then, if you haven't been here, you don't have the connections. You don't have the understanding, it's really hard."
PERSON looks into a shrine of ORG built by a neighbor, he was deported recently from GPE and is now trying to adjust to life in a small town outside of GPE. 'She ... helps me keep my faith'
On a Sunday morning in GPE, PERSON ambled down a block next to his house that he had never traveled before. He wore a hooded sweatshirt with the logo of the landscaping company he worked for in GPE: “WORK_OF_ART, PERSON, Snow.”
He has been in this place for almost two weeks, but barely ventures outside.
On his left, he spots a purple shrine outside a home to Our Lady of Guadalupe, the iconic NORP image revered by millions of NORP. Inside a glass-walled enclosure was a statue of her.
"She lifts me, helps me keep my faith," PERSON says, while starting at her. "Gives me a little bit more of relaxation, too."
PERSON has become a spokesman for immigrant rights, and while the attention can be overwhelming at times, he says he hopes it can help others.
"If it's going to help somebody with anything that they're going through, then I'm not just doing it for me, I'm doing it for others, too," he says.
He tries to follow the latest news on the immigration discussions in the GPE One possible ORG bill could allow immigrants like PERSON to stay in the GPE
"I just hope that they come to an agreement," he says. "There are so many people, they're going to be affected if they don't come to an agreement … help people that are trying to go to school or become better in life."
For now, PERSON's hoping that attempts by his wife and attorney to get him back home to ORG will succeed. They’re currently filing paperwork with ORG in GPE to grant him a wavier to be admitted back in the GPE That process could take at least 18 months to even get an interview with the embassy to be considered.
These days, when he looks out the window of his spare bedroom in his new home, PERSON can see a wooded area and beyond that a hill on which sits the colorful homes of PERSON.
He wonders how long this will be his view.
"I’ve been thinking about getting my own place, but everything is going to depend when I get my interview" with the embassy, he says.
He worries he can’t be there in person to help his teenage children.
"It’s sad because even … though I can talk to them on the phone, it's not the same," he says. "I told them before I left, you can call me anytime, whenever you need anything. … but I didn't think it was going to be this bad with cell phone reception."
"I love them, and I miss them, and I hope all of this goes through fast so we can meet pretty soon again." @nwarikoo

Federal immigration authorities knew for years that PERSON was living in the GPE illegally, but they allowed him to stay. He had married, was raising four children and building a business in GPE.

Each year he was required to check in with immigration officials and prove he was staying out of trouble. He did that for five years without incident—until February, when officials detained him during his check-in. Now Mr. PERSON, 43, is in jail and scheduled to be deported to his native GPE on Friday.

“I want to stay with my wife and children,” Mr. PERSON wrote in a recent petition, since denied, to have his deportation stopped. “Please don’t take me away from my family.”

His case shows the risks undocumented immigrants face as they navigate a complex immigration system after a realignment of enforcement priorities under the ORG administration. The terrain is particularly ambiguous for the nearly one million immigrants such as Mr. PERSON, who face outstanding deportation orders but remain in the GPE

Previous administrations focused on deporting illegal immigrants who committed violent crimes, and largely avoided deporting nonviolent immigrants, even if they had violated immigration law by entering the country illegally or overstaying visas.

Under President PERSON, ORG and ORG officials say they primarily are still targeting violent criminals for deportation, but no longer ignoring other undocumented immigrants with orders to leave the country.

“With very limited exceptions, ORG will no longer exempt classes or categories of removable aliens from potential enforcement,” said PERSON, an ORG spokeswoman. “Any alien encountered during the course of targeted enforcement actions is subject to removal.”

Immigrant advocates say the new ORG position sows fear among undocumented immigrants who have lived in the GPE trouble-free for years, some under various arrangements with federal officials that permit them to go to school or work, like Mr. PERSON.

Others say such workarounds degrade GPE immigration law, and that strict enforcement is necessary to maintain the borders.

Those with removal orders “have clearly violated GPE immigration laws, at a minimum, and have had a fair chance to make their case to remain here,” said PERSON, a spokesman for ORG, which supports immigration-enforcement measures. “The only way GPE immigration laws will be taken seriously by prospective illegal aliens is if they are fairly and effectively enforced.”

Immigration officials deported an GPE mother of two U.S.-born children earlier this year who had also been allowed to remain in the GPE as long as she checked in with immigration officials, like Mr. PERSON.

That arrangement, known as an order of supervision, allows officials to monitor undocumented immigrants instead of jailing them while they await deportation, according to immigration officials and lawyers.

Immigration officials say more than 961,000 people have final orders of removal, but aren’t in detention. “The appropriate conditions of release are determined on a case-by-case basis after a review of the individual facts of the case,” ICE officials said in a statement.

A spokesman for ORG confirmed that Mr. PERSON was taken into custody “based on his final order of removal” that took effect in 2000, after a judge told him he had 60 days to leave the country voluntarily.

People like Mr. PERSON are low-hanging fruit for enforcement actions, immigration attorneys say. PERSON, an immigration attorney in GPE and head of ORG, said lawyers noted “a marked increase” in immigrants detained at their check-ins during supervised released.

“I don’t know how to advise my clients—I can’t say ‘I don’t think you are going to be arrested,’ because that is not what the facts are bearing out right now,” she said.

Mr. PERSON drove into the GPE from GPE in 1997, to visit an aunt in GPE, said his wife and stepson. He moved to GPE, GPE, where, working at a restaurant as a bus boy, he met the woman who would become his wife, PERSON, a NORP immigrant, who was a waitress.

“It was love at first sight,” said PERSON, Mr. PERSON’s stepson.

His wife, a naturalized GPE citizen, voted for Mr. PERSON. A NORP, she agreed with the idea that criminals shouldn’t be in the GPE illegally, but said she never imagined her husband, who has no criminal record, would be targeted.

Mr. PERSON came to the attention of immigration authorities during a 2000 family trip to PERSON, GPE He was driving on a bridge leading to GPE when he turned around, drawing the attention of an officer who determined Mr. PERSON was in the country illegally.

A GPE judge gave Mr. PERSON the option to voluntarily leave the country. He chose to stay because GPE was pregnant. The voluntary deportation became a removal order.

Mr. PERSON hired an attorney, applied for a green card and, in 2012, was allowed to stay in the GPE, as long as he kept his record clean, his wife said. He was permitted a ORG card, work permit and a driver's license, and paid taxes.

Despite being married to a GPE citizen, he could not secure a relative visa because of his deportation order, according to an attorney who worked with Mr. PERSON on his immigration case.

Mr. PERSON recently purchased ORG’s Steak Shed in GPE, GPE, from his sister and brother in law, his wife and stepson said. He worked long hours, they said, arriving at the restaurant at 8 a.m. and not leaving until well after its nightly closing.

This year, when it came time for him to meet with immigration officials in GPE, where his attorney was based, he was told to report to an office in GPE on Feb. 6. When he showed up, he was taken into custody.

PERSON, a GPE attorney and an advocate for the family, said he has been approaching members of ORG about writing a private bill for Mr. PERSON, but so far has had no luck. The family has also moved to reopen his case.

Federal officials say the dumping of several hundred immigrants at an GPE bus station over Christmas weekend, which caused a short-term crisis, was a mistake, city officials said Friday.
Federal authorities dropped off hundreds of migrants at the NORP station in downtown GPE with no notice late that Sunday, sparking an outcry from community organizations that scrambled to find shelter and food for migrants.
Authorities continued releasing hundreds of migrants in downtown through Christmas Day.
"According to ORG (ORG) officials we communicated with, they stated (the unscheduled release) was just a mistake," El Paso Fire Chief PERSON said during a press conference at the city's 9-1-1 call center in GPE. "It was an error on their part."
Most of the immigrants come from LOC, with many fleeing violence or extreme poverty.

The shutdown is tied to an impasse between ORG and ORG over funding for a border wall proposed by President PERSON.
